Pourquoi est-ce que je n'aime pas les switch ?

Ayant travaillÃ© sur des langages bas niveaux, ou qui proposaient des implÃ©mentations complÃ¨tes du switch comprenant des Goto (afin de passer d'un case Ã  l'autre) 
Aujourd'hui oÃ¹ je fais principalement du Typescript, je suis un poil frustrÃ© et je boude ce switch !

Par rapport Ã  un if/else, je vois ces problÃ¨mes :

1ï¸âƒ£ Fall-through source d'erreurs
L'oubli d'un break dans un switch entraÃ®ne l'exÃ©cution involontaire des cas suivants, rendant le dÃ©bug difficile.

2ï¸âƒ£ LisibilitÃ© et maintenance
Un switch avec de nombreux cas devient rapidement illisible et difficile Ã  maintenir.

3ï¸âƒ£ Limitation des expressions
Le switch ne gÃ¨re que des comparaisons d'Ã©galitÃ© simples. Le if/else supporte des conditions complexes (ex. value > 10 && value < 20).

4ï¸âƒ£ Performance Ã©quivalente
En JavaScript/TypeScript, le switch n'apporte souvent aucun gain de performance par rapport Ã  un if/else bien structurÃ©.

5ï¸âƒ£ Manque d'extensibilitÃ©
Ajouter de nouveaux cas dans un switch va Ã  l'encontre du principe ouvert/fermÃ© (OCP). Un if/else avec des fonctions ou objets de mapping est plus Ã©volutif.

Bref au final je l'utilise jamais.

Demain je vous propose une alternative moins verbeuse et donc plus concise, extensible, tout en restant lisible et idiomatique.

highlightedComments:
This is just a preference, I try to respect the â€œParse, don't validateâ€ principle as much as possible to ensure that the objects I own are valid when they are created, not afterwards. In this way, I can be sure that the objects manipulated in the handler are valid when received, which removes the need for handler validation (and therefore less code).

If I can take your example, CREATE and UPDATE commands should contains domain objects containing the validation (ex: it contains goat's name that should be between 6 and 20 characters). Both commands will contains a Name object that contains this rule, so you don't have to rewrite it inside the handler. It just takes to create the command from the input by using domain objects before sending it inside the dispatcher.
If you add a rule tomorrow, it will impact the domain object (which should contains this rule), and both commands will be impacted at the same time.

It's really my preference to limit the amount of code in the handler, and above all, to avoid having commands that aren't valid.

data.text:
ğŸ’¡ Are you exposing MediatR commands in your API?
Stop. Right. Now. 

No, seriously. I just spent days debugging issues caused by this exact "shortcut" ğŸ˜…

The use of minimal APIs and the exposure of commands to implement DDD patterns via MediatR are everywhere at the moment.
It's naive to think there's no impact, and it's important to understand them.

Input deserialization is at the heart of an API, and must be possible at all costs.

Why?

Because once deserialized, it is possible to apply input validation rules to return explicit errors (e.g. must contain at least 8 characters...).
By making the query object too complex, you reduce the chances of deserialization.

That's why it's important to separate the request from the command.

Your API is your contract with the world.

Want to do it right?
1. Create simple input models
2. Map them to commands (and apply validation here)
3. Control your error messages
4. Sleep better at night ğŸ˜´

Your future self will thank you!

For a concrete example, read the article in the comments section.

data.text:
ğŸ’¡ Are you exposing MediatR commands in your API?
Stop. Right. Now. 

No, seriously. I just spent days debugging issues caused by this exact "shortcut" ğŸ˜…

The use of minimal APIs and the exposure of commands to implement DDD patterns via MediatR are everywhere at the moment.
It's naive to think there's no impact, and it's important to understand them.

Input deserialization is at the heart of an API, and must be possible at all costs.

Why?

Because once deserialized, it is possible to apply input validation rules to return explicit errors (e.g. must contain at least 8 characters...).
By making the query object too complex, you reduce the chances of deserialization.

That's why it's important to separate the request from the command.

Your API is your contract with the world.

Want to do it right?
1. Create simple input models
2. Map them to commands (and apply validation here)
3. Control your error messages
4. Sleep better at night ğŸ˜´

Your future self will thank you!

For a concrete example, read the article in the comments section.
